title: Lawmakers forcing slow-moving NCAA to pick up the pace of change
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Former NBPA Executive Director Charles Grantham spoke with Trysta Krick about his feelings on compensation for collegiate athletes. USA TODAY

The NCAA has a choice. It can get on board or risk getting run over. It can craft legislation that embraces change or invite change being thrust down its intransigent throats.

There is still time to get ahead of California’s Fair Pay To Play Act and the like-minded legislation gaining traction in other states; still time to create a progressive national policy on the compensation of college athletes; still time to act before Congress asserts jurisdiction.

That time, however, is not unlimited. Though California Bill 206 does not take effect until 2023, other states and multiple U.S. Congressmen are contemplating similar legislation on faster tracks. With the most recent Seton Hall sports poll showing Americans favor college athletes being able to profit off their name, image and likeness by a 60-32 margin (with 8% undecided), the pace of change appears to be accelerating.

The NCAA logo is displayed at midcourt of an NCAA tournament game. (Photo: Matt Slocum, AP)

“I would hope that they would see the tea leaves; that this is coming in some form or fashion,” said Ohio University professor David Ridpath, interim president of the Drake Group. “They’re not going to be able to stop this train. . .

“It’s a fairness issue. We’ve jumped the shark. We’ve got coaches making millions of dollars, you’ve got a (multi) billion-dollar TV contract with March Madness. With so much money coming in, to tell an individual that they don’t have the right to own their own image is flat-out wrong.”

SEISMIC CHANGE: Recruiting will shift if endorsements come to college sports

MAJOR VALUE: Elite college athletes could be worth millions if change happen

LAW IMPACT: NCAA president says athletes could turn into employees

Former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice acknowledged the inequities of the status quo last spring in submitting the report of her Commission on College Basketball, but she resisted making specific recommendations on name, image and likeness (NIL) at that time in deference to pending court cases. Eighteen months later, the NCAA’s Board of Governors is expected to hear proposals from a Federal and State Legislation Working Group on Oct. 29.

Tick, tock.

"While we have made significant progress in recent years, we have not always responded to the needs and rights of our players swiftly,” Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski said during the Atlantic Coast Conference’s Operation Basketball media day. “And frankly, we're playing catch-up after years of stagnant rules.

“I hope and trust that not only will there be a plan to put the student-athletes' best interests at the forefront, but that we'll also have a firm plan for implementation at the national level."

What shape that might take is speculative. Ohio State athletic director Gene Smith, who co-chairs the working group, is on record that its recommendations “will not result in paying students as employees.” Yet while NCAA President Mark Emmert has called the California bill an “existential threat” to the collegiate model, and has responded by raising the possibility of California schools being ineligible for NCAA championships, he has also said the vast majority of college presidents and athletic administrators, “recognize this is an area where we need to continue to evolve out rules.”

Evolution, of course, can be unpredictable. To some, it means adaptation; to others, extinction. While Texas Tech athletic director Kirby Hocutt is a self-proclaimed “strong proponent of giving our student-athletes the same rights that any student on our campus has,” Texas Christian AD Jeremiah Donati remains reluctant to abandon NCAA-style amateurism.

“I just think it’d be a shame to throw it away so haphazardly. ...” Donati told the Fort Worth Star-Telegram last month. “It has potential to be a wild, wild west situation, which is scary as an athletic director.”

Uncertainties abound. While a handful of college athletes have built personal brands appealing to national advertisers – basketball star Zion Williamson had more than a million Instagram followers before he committed to Duke last year – the threat of local boosters turning recruiting battles into bidding wars is a widespread concern.

“Elite athletes could get a couple hundred thousand a year; I think that’s very reasonable to expect,” said A.J. Maestas, CEO of Navigate Research, a Chicago-based firm that specializes in college and professional sports rights valuations. “What’s really difficult to tell is how much of that would be because of the actual economic value of their name, image, likeness as an endorser and how much of that would be just the local interest in attracting those athletes. So I’m guessing that the part that is difficult to predict for us is how much of this would be above-the-table, legalized recruiting efforts.”

The Drake Group, an organization formed to promote “academic integrity in collegiate sport,” has issued a position paper proposing that boosters be prohibited from making endorsement deals with college athletes. South Dakota State AD Justin Snell, meanwhile, is not convinced there’s a problem in need of solving.

“Media covers this in a way that every student-athlete is like an Alabama football player or a Kentucky basketball player,” Snell said. “And if you’re involved in it, you know that 98 percent of the student-athletes never experience anything like that.”

For the overwhelming majority of college athletes, a scholarship amounts to a windfall that can ease a family’s financial burden and eliminate years of student debt. But as the salaries of coaches, administrators and conference commissioners have skyrocketed, athletes’ share of the overall pie has shrunk while the perception of exploitation has grown.

According to data submitted to the U.S. Department of Education for the 2017-18 fiscal year, the 10 schools that generated the most athletic revenue paid 762 coaches $256.6 million in salary while spending $101 million less on financial aid to their 6,804 athletes. Texas A&M and Florida State both spent more than $2.60 on coaches' salaries for every dollar spent on scholarships.

University financial reports submitted to the NCAA show an even greater gap: $292.7 million in coaches' compensation (including bonuses and benefits) against $161 million in financial aid for athletes.

From disparity comes discontent.

“Why does any kid have to pay to go to the University of Alabama?” asked Diana Taurasi, the former University of Connecticut women’s basketball star. “I don’t get it. Off one bowl game this year, they can cover everyone’s tuition. Why shouldn’t that be a free school to go to if you can get in and your academic standard and all that. Why should you pay $30,000 to go to a school that’s making an abundant amount of money? That’s ludicrous.”

That’s how things work in college athletics. Because university athletic departments operate on a not-for-profit basis, they generally spend what a bottom-line business might show as a surplus. Two of the three schools to report more than $200 million in athletic revenues for the 2017-18 fiscal year – Texas and Ohio State – both spent more than $200 million on their sports programs during the same period. Because of NCAA regulations and scholarship limitations, much of that spending is devoted to facilities and amenities that aid recruiting but add no cash to athletes’ pockets.

“I do think there are a lot of things we can do for student-athletes to give them more opportunities and more money, but don’t think (the California bill) is the right way to do it,” New Mexico State football coach Doug Martin said. “In my opinion, this is going to destroy college athletics. States like New Mexico, you are not going to have college athletics. Only the power conference schools will be able to survive this in my opinion because they are going to have the money to do it. Nobody else is going to be able to sustain what they are doing.”

With the benefit of his school’s power conference affiliation, Florida State football coach Willie Taggart, sees California’s Fair Pay To Play Act as “a helluva bill.”

“If they can profit from their likeness, I think that’s fair,” Taggart said. “I mean, it’s a new time. We don’t live where we used to live. We don’t live there anymore. Times are different. You always hear people talk about doing what’s best for the student-athlete. ... I think them profiting from their likeness is good. I do think they should get it when they graduate.

“I think that’s the ultimate goal when you go to school is to graduate, and I think personally – and I think we all know – we all graduated from school knowing that that’s when you need the money the most.”

Still to be determined is how much and how soon money may be made available to college athletes, what rules the NCAA might enact to regulate that commerce, and whether change can be agreed upon before it is imposed by politicians.

“They can be proactive or they can end up being reactive and it will be done for them,” Ridpath said. “I agree with the NCAA that it should be able to make its own rules, but the rules have to be constitutional. They have to be fair. And I think, honestly, from the federal perspective, they have to be forced. And this is eventually going to force them to do something.”

With contributions from Evan Barnes, Memphis Commercial Appeal; Steve Berkowitz, USA Today; Charles Bryce, San Angelo Standard-Times; Jason Groves, Las Cruces Sun-News; Emily Horos, The Arizona Republic; Kelly Lyell, The Coloradoan; Wayne McGahee III, Tallahassee Democrat, Jeff Metcalfe, The Arizona Republic; Fletcher Page, Cincinnati Enquirer; Cameron Teague Robinson, Louisville Courier Journal; Orion Sang, Detroit Free Press; Adam Sparks, The Tennessean; Blake Toppmeyer, Knoxville News Sentinel; Josh Vitale, Montgomery Advertiser; Curt Weiler, Tallahassee Democrat; Mike Wilson, Knoxville News Sentinel; Matt Zimmer, Sioux Falls Argus-Leader.
description: California's Fair Pay To Play Act and pushes by other lawmakers are forcing the NCAA to pick up the pace of change to deal with the amateurism issues.
